field.description: Road freight encompasses the movement of goods by trucks and other road vehicles, including full truckload (FTL), less-than-truckload (LTL), drayage, intermodal, and cross-border trucking operations.

problems.title: Chronic Driver Shortage and High Turnover Crisis in Trucking Industry
problems.description: The trucking industry faces a persistent driver shortage that has reached critical levels, with the American Trucking Associations reporting a shortage of 80,000 drivers in 2021, projected to reach 160,000 by 2030. However, industry experts argue this is fundamentally a turnover and retention problem rather than a true labor shortage. Long-haul trucking experiences turnover rates exceeding 90%, with some carriers operating at over 100% annual turnover. The root causes include poor working conditions, unpaid detention time at shipping facilities, inadequate compensation structures that fail to account for non-driving work hours, restrictive Hours of Service regulations, and the demographic challenge of an aging workforce with insufficient younger replacements. Federal requirements mandating drivers be 21 years old for interstate commerce further limit the recruitment pool. The industry's image problem, combined with extended time away from home and inconsistent schedules, makes trucking careers unappealing to younger workers.
problems.summary: The trucking industry struggles with 90%+ driver turnover rates and projected shortages of 160,000 drivers by 2030, driven by poor working conditions, unpaid time, aging demographics, and regulatory barriers to younger workforce entry.

problems.title: Double Brokering and Freight Fraud Epidemic Causing Billions in Annual Losses
problems.description: Double brokering has emerged as one of the most disruptive forms of fraud in the freight industry, with occurrences increasing 400% year-over-year from 2021-2022. The practice occurs when a freight broker tenders a load to a carrier who then illegally re-brokers it to another carrier without authorization, often disappearing with payment before the actual hauler is compensated. Fraud-related losses in trucking exceeded $800 million in 2023, with double brokering alone accounting for $500-700 million annually according to the Wall Street Journal. Sophisticated fraud rings now operate like businesses, using multiple phones, stolen carrier identities, spoofed insurance certificates, and fake email addresses. The problem has worsened due to remote work reducing oversight, the ease of obtaining motor carrier authority, and inadequate identity verification systems. In surveys, 50% of freight brokers cite double brokering as their top fraud concern, with 85% reporting they have been directly impacted.

problems.title: Nuclear Verdicts and Litigation Crisis Devastating Trucking Insurance Markets
problems.description: The trucking industry faces an escalating insurance and litigation crisis driven by 'nuclear verdicts' - jury awards exceeding $10 million that have become increasingly common in trucking accident cases. According to ATRI research, average verdict sizes in trucking cases increased 967% between 2010 and 2018, with the average verdict now exceeding $27.5 million. Third-party litigation funding, where investors finance lawsuits in exchange for a portion of settlements, has amplified plaintiff strategies and prolonged litigation. This has caused commercial trucking insurance premiums to skyrocket, with some carriers seeing 30-50% annual increases. Lawsuit abuse reform and insurance availability have climbed to the number two and three positions respectively in ATRI's annual industry concerns ranking. Small and medium carriers are particularly impacted, with some being forced out of business or unable to obtain adequate coverage. The crisis has also led to defensive driving behaviors that may paradoxically reduce efficiency and increase other safety risks.
problems.summary: Nuclear verdicts averaging $27.5 million and 967% increase in trucking lawsuit awards since 2010 have created an insurance crisis, with premiums rising 30-50% annually and threatening the viability of small carriers.

problems.title: Critical Truck Parking Shortage Creating Safety Hazards Nationwide
problems.description: The United States faces a severe shortage of safe truck parking spaces, with estimates indicating a deficit of over 40,000 spaces nationally. Truck drivers spend an average of 56 minutes per day searching for parking, resulting in significant lost productivity and safety risks. The National Transportation Safety Board has designated truck parking as a safety issue, noting that drivers unable to find legal parking often park illegally on highway shoulders, ramps, or in unsafe locations, contributing to accidents. The problem has worsened as freight volumes have increased while parking infrastructure development has not kept pace. Hours of Service regulations compound the issue by requiring drivers to stop within specific time windows regardless of parking availability. The parking crisis intersects with driver quality of life concerns, contributing to high turnover rates as drivers cite parking difficulty as a major frustration with the profession.

problems.title: EPA 2027 Emissions Regulations Creating Significant Cost and Technology Challenges
problems.description: The EPA's 2027 emissions regulations represent the most stringent heavy-duty vehicle emissions standards in history, requiring an 80%+ reduction in NOx emissions and 50% reduction in particulate matter compared to current standards. The rules also extend warranty requirements to 450,000 miles and useful life limits to 650,000 miles. For fleets, this translates to an estimated $20,000-40,000 price increase per new diesel truck, with current Class 8 trucks priced at $180,000-200,000 potentially rising to $220,000+. The regulations also set aggressive zero-emission vehicle targets, requiring roughly 25% of long-haul trucks sold by 2032 to be zero-emission vehicles, despite only 0.3% of 2023 heavy-duty truck sales being ZEVs. Industry groups argue the timeline is unrealistic given current electric truck costs of $350,000-500,000 and the lack of charging infrastructure. The regulatory landscape faces additional uncertainty with potential policy changes from the incoming administration.
problems.summary: EPA 2027 emissions rules requiring 80%+ NOx reduction will increase new truck costs by $20,000-40,000 while zero-emission mandates face infrastructure gaps, with electric trucks costing 2-3x conventional vehicles.

problems.title: Historic Freight Recession Creating Prolonged Market Instability and Carrier Failures
problems.description: The trucking industry has experienced what ATRI describes as a 'historic freight recession' lasting over three years, making it the longest downturn in modern industry history. The economy remains the number one concern for trucking companies for the third consecutive year, with freight rates and tonnage remaining flat while operational costs continue to surge. This margin squeeze has forced difficult decisions including cost-cutting, layoffs, and carriers leaving the industry entirely. The 2020-2021 pandemic boom created a capacity bubble as new carriers entered the market, followed by demand normalization that left significant overcapacity. Spot rates have fallen dramatically from pandemic peaks, and contract rates have compressed. Small and medium carriers have been disproportionately affected, with thousands exiting the market since 2022. The prolonged downturn has also created a 'survival mode' mentality that may delay necessary investments in safety, technology, and driver welfare.
problems.summary: A historic three-year freight recession has created severe margin pressure with flat rates and rising costs, causing thousands of carrier failures and industry-wide financial stress unprecedented in modern trucking history.

problems.title: Rising Fuel Costs and Operational Expense Volatility Squeezing Carrier Margins
problems.description: Fuel costs represent the largest single expense for most trucking operations, and volatile fuel prices create significant financial planning challenges. Beyond fuel, carriers face escalating costs across multiple categories including insurance premiums (rising 30-50% annually), equipment prices, maintenance costs, and labor expenses. The combination of flat or declining freight rates with rising operational costs has created an unprecedented margin squeeze. Many carriers operate on thin margins of 3-5%, leaving little room to absorb cost increases. The unpredictability of fuel prices makes long-term contract pricing difficult, while fuel surcharge mechanisms often lag actual price movements. Small carriers and owner-operators are particularly vulnerable as they lack the scale to negotiate favorable fuel prices or absorb temporary spikes. This cost pressure contributes to the broader industry financial stress and carrier exit trends.
problems.summary: Volatile fuel costs combined with surging insurance, equipment, and labor expenses are creating severe margin pressure for carriers already operating on 3-5% margins amid flat freight rates.

problems.title: Hours of Service Regulations Reducing Operational Flexibility and Driver Productivity
problems.description: Federal Hours of Service (HOS) regulations limit commercial drivers to 11 hours of driving within a 14-hour on-duty window, followed by mandatory 10-hour rest periods. While designed for safety, these rules create significant operational challenges and are a top driver complaint. The regulations restrict drivers' ability to work efficiently, particularly when combined with unpredictable detention times at shipping facilities. Electronic Logging Devices (ELDs), mandated since 2017, enforce strict compliance but remove the flexibility drivers previously had to manage their schedules. Many drivers feel these regulations make their jobs harder without improving their pay or working conditions, as they cannot adjust for traffic, weather, or facility delays. The rigid rules also intersect with the parking shortage, forcing drivers to stop within specific time windows regardless of parking availability. The HOS framework has remained largely unchanged despite industry calls for reform to allow more flexibility while maintaining safety standards.
problems.summary: Hours of Service regulations limiting drivers to 11 hours of driving with mandatory rest periods reduce operational flexibility and, combined with ELD enforcement, are a major driver complaint contributing to turnover.

problems.title: Detention Time at Shipping Facilities Causing Unpaid Work and Driver Dissatisfaction
problems.description: Excessive detention time at shipping and receiving facilities represents one of the most significant yet underaddressed problems in trucking. Drivers frequently wait hours beyond scheduled appointment times for loading or unloading, time that often goes uncompensated or is paid at rates far below driving pay. OOIDA and other driver advocacy groups identify detention as a root cause of driver dissatisfaction and turnover. The problem is systemic: shippers and receivers face no penalty for inefficient dock operations while drivers bear the cost of lost driving time, reduced miles, and HOS clock erosion. Average detention times have increased as supply chains have become more just-in-time and facilities operate at capacity. While some carriers charge detention fees after 2-4 hours, collection is inconsistent and rates are often inadequate. The lack of industry standards for detention compensation perpetuates a system that effectively transfers costs from shippers to carriers and drivers.
problems.summary: Excessive unpaid detention time at shipping facilities causes drivers to wait hours without compensation, eroding HOS clocks and earning potential, and is a primary driver of workforce dissatisfaction and turnover.

problems.title: Technology Adoption Gaps Limiting Efficiency and Competitiveness in Trucking
problems.description: Despite the availability of advanced technologies for fleet management, route optimization, predictive maintenance, and real-time visibility, significant adoption gaps persist across the trucking industry. Many carriers, particularly small and medium-sized operators, continue to rely on manual processes, basic spreadsheets, and phone-based dispatch. The technology gap creates competitive disadvantages, operational inefficiencies, and missed opportunities for cost savings. Barriers to adoption include high implementation costs, lack of technical expertise, integration challenges with existing systems, and resistance to change. The fragmented nature of the industry with over 90% of carriers operating 6 or fewer trucks makes enterprise technology solutions impractical for many. Additionally, the rapid pace of technology change creates uncertainty about which solutions will provide lasting value. This technology gap also extends to data analytics, where many carriers lack the ability to leverage operational data for decision-making despite generating vast amounts of information through ELDs and telematics.
problems.summary: Significant technology adoption gaps persist in trucking, with many carriers lacking modern TMS, analytics, and automation capabilities due to cost barriers, expertise gaps, and the fragmented nature of the industry.

problems.title: Cross-Border Trucking Complexity and Trade Uncertainty Disrupting North American Freight
problems.description: Cross-border trucking between the US, Canada, and Mexico faces increasing complexity from trade policy uncertainty, regulatory differences, and operational challenges. Recent tariff discussions and trade policy shifts have created planning uncertainty for carriers operating international routes. Border crossing delays can add hours to transit times, with wait times varying unpredictably. Different regulatory requirements between countries, including driver qualification, vehicle standards, and Hours of Service rules, create compliance complexity. The drayage segment connecting ports and rail terminals to cross-border facilities faces particular challenges with congestion and equipment availability. Cabotage restrictions prevent foreign carriers from operating domestic routes, limiting operational flexibility. Currency fluctuations add financial planning complexity for carriers operating across borders. The USMCA trade agreement provides some framework but ongoing trade tensions and potential policy changes create persistent uncertainty for carriers investing in cross-border operations.
